title: Polar Equation of Conic
text:
For a conic with a focus at the origin, if the directrix is $$x=p$$ or $$x=-p$$, where $$p$$ is a positive real number, and the eccentricity is a positive real number e, the conic has a polar equation
$$r= rac{e p}{1+e cos\left(	hetaight)}$$ or $$r= rac{e p}{1-e cos\left(	hetaight)}$$
For a conic with a focus at the origin, if the directrix is $$y=p$$ or $$y=-p$$, where $$p$$ is a positive real number, and the eccentricity is a positive real number e, the conic has a polar equation
$$r= rac{e p}{1+e sin\left(	hetaight)}$$ or $$r= rac{e p}{1-e sin\left(	hetaight)}$$

 r is equal to fraction, e p, over, 1 plus ecos of theta,   or  r is equal to fraction, e p, over, 1 minus ecos of theta,  
For a conic with a focus at the origin, if the directrix is  y is equal to p  or  y, is equal to, negative p , where  p  is a positive real number, and the eccentricity is a positive real number e, the conic has a polar equation
 r is equal to fraction, e p, over, 1 plus esin of theta,   or  r is equal to fraction, e p, over, 1 minus esin of theta,

title: Standard Form
text: We want to multiply the numerator and denominator by the reciprocal of the constant of the original equation, $$\frac{1}{c}$$, where c is the constant so that we can change the equation to the standard polar form. What is the reciprocal that we want to multiply?
speech: We want to multiply the numerator and denominator by the reciprocal of the constant of the original equation,  1 over c , where c is the constant so that we can change the equation to the standard polar form. What is the reciprocal that we want to multiply?

, where c is the constant so that we can change the equation to the standard polar form. What is the reciprocal that we want to multiply?

title: Standard Form
text: After multiplying by the reciprocal of the constant, what is the polar equation now?
speech: After multiplying by the reciprocal of the constant, what is the polar equation now?

title: Eccentricity
text: In the standard polar form, the coefficient in front of $$sin\left(\theta\right)$$ or $$cos\left(\theta\right)$$ is the eccentricity. What is the eccentricity?
speech: In the standard polar form, the coefficient in front of , sine of theta,  or  cosine of theta  is the eccentricity. What is the eccentricity?

title: Directrix
text: Since $$sin\left(\theta\right)$$ is in the denominator, is the directrix along the $$y$$ or $$x$$ axis?

title: Directrix
text: The numerator is the product of the eccentricity and the directrix. Now that we know the eccentricity and numerator, what is the directrix?
speech: The numerator is the product of the eccentricity and the directrix. Now that we know the eccentricity and numerator, what is the directrix?
pacedSpeech: The numerator is the product of the eccentricity and the directrix. Now that we know the eccentricity and numerator, what is the directrix?

title: Type of Conic
text:
For a conic with eccentricity e,
- if $$0 \leq e<1$$, the conic is ellipse
- if $$e=1$$. the conic is a parabola
- if $$e>1$$, the conic is a hyperbola

- if  e, is greater than 1 , the conic is a hyperbola

title: Type of Conic
text: Given that we have found the eccentricity $$e=\frac{5}{4}$$, what type of conic is this?
